19.42.text: In 2011, when these three nice gentlemen

23.25.text:
gave us an offer
we couldn't refuse at AdMob

26.53.text: and we sold it for 750 million dollars,

31.02.text:
that gave me an opportunity, I suppose,
to re-evaluate my life and goals

35.41.text: and decide what I wanted to do next.

37.99.text:
And, my idea was basically,
to help the UK to be

42.30.text:
a better place to start
and run a tech startup.

45.41.text: That was my big, hairy ambition,

47.58.text:
and obviously, the emphasis there was on
helping rather than doing it all myself.

51.44.text: I did that in two ways: first of all,

60.50.text:
what I identified as being
one of the most important things

63.30.text:
was investing in startups and helping
them financially to get going.

68.09.text:
But probably the most important part
of it was actually to become a mentor.

72.60.text:
This gentleman, on your right,
is the original mentor, called Mentor,

78.36.text: fair enough, from whom we get the name.

80.55.text:
And he helped Telemachus to be inspired
to go off and do whatever he was doing.

87.19.text:
Mentor himself actually
wasn't a very good teacher.

90.55.text:
He was occasionally occupied
by the goddess Athena

93.69.text:
who used him as a sort of vehicle
to give great advice,

96.63.text: and that is where the name came from.

98.82.text: Unlike a lot of angel investors,

101.32.text:
I wanted to actually get involved
and mentor the companies I invested in.

108.41.text:
Since then I've invested in 25 companies,
and I've also joined the government

113.09.text:
to help startups fundraise
in what's called the Afterburner program,

117.87.text:
which I will talk about
a little more in a minute.

120.64.text:
I've also joined Techstars accelerator
which helps startups,

126.67.text:
around 100 companies
since I started to do this.

130.11.text:
These are the particularly successful ones
that have gone on to raise

133.41.text:
Series A funding
from venture capitalists,

135.78.text:
so they are well on their way
to becoming hopefully future AdMob's.

142.52.text:
Is something I've noticed while I've been
mentoring these 100-odd companies,

146.39.text:
is that how these founders
think about mentoring

150.19.text: actually is a predictor of their success.

152.88.text:
The ones who attract mentors,
attract lots of mentors,

157.51.text:
and then actually manage to be
singularly disrespectful of their time.

161.71.text:
In other words, they get much more time
out of these important people

165.79.text:
than they would
perhaps deserve, is a real skill.

169.98.text: Something which these guys have mastered,

172.49.text:
and hopefully, will go on to master
for other people as well.

176.47.text: But I think the corollary is also true.

179.01.text:
The people who don't master mentoring,
never seem to get off the ground.

184.18.text:
So if I invest in a company,
and I don't hear from them for a month,

187.49.text: I've sort of mentally written them off,

189.51.text:
because they are not going
to master the skill.

191.76.text:
They think they are going to be doing it
on their own, and that's a fallacy.

195.40.text: They won't be able to do it.

196.88.text:
So great mentors attract great founders,
and great founders attract great mentors,

203.50.text: So what does mentoring mean exactly?

206.77.text:
First of all, it's somebody who is going
to help you repeat their success.

211.48.text: Somebody who has done it before

213.39.text:
and who will help you
on your journey in startup world,

216.80.text:
or indeed any new skill
you're likely to master.

219.68.text: As an example, if you want to learn polo,

222.57.text:
the person who is going to be able
to teach you best

225.05.text:
is the best person
you know who can play polo.

227.56.text:
Not somebody who doesn't know
how to mount a horse.

230.74.text:
It can actually be around
one specific area.

233.86.text:
For instance, we often hear these days
of young people mentoring older people

237.53.text:
about things like social
networking and technology.

240.17.text:
But where it's effective
in my life about mentoring

243.15.text:
is the Afterburner program
I mentioned before.

245.97.text:
In the UK, startups find it difficult
to go on to raise Series A funding,

250.34.text:
so it's quite easy to raise
their initial little seed fund round,

253.48.text: but to go and get a venture capitalist

255.40.text:
to actually invest in you
and your company is notoriously difficult.

259.68.text:
So when I joined the government I was
asked how we would tackle this issue.

265.66.text: Having a little bit of experience in this

268.97.text:
I decided that the fundamental issue
wasn't the companies weren't good enough,

272.66.text: it's just that they weren't very good

274.44.text:
at actually raising money
from venture capitalists.

277.02.text:
They didn't know what to say,
their pitch decks weren't very good,

280.20.text: their presentation style wasn't very good

282.21.text:
so mentoring around a specific topic which
you want to master is really important.

286.09.text:
I'm pleased to say
that with Charles [surname]

288.44.text:
my colleague out in California
who helps with this process,

291.46.text: that since April of last year, April 2014,

294.38.text:
we've gone on to raise 50 million dollars
for the companies we've been mentoring.

299.16.text:
So I think that proves that mentoring
around a subject, as well as generally,

304.77.text: You want to avoid bad actors.

309.94.text:
Unfortunately, Sylvester Stallone won
the Worst Actor of the 20th Century Award

317.08.text:
But in the context of mentoring
what does that mean?

320.20.text: Well, I think there are two things:

322.23.text:
one of which is
have they done this before?

326.10.text:
A lot of people try to get into mentoring
when they aren't ready,

329.26.text:
or they haven't got
the right skills to teach.

331.83.text:
But I think more importantly
it's an attitude thing;

335.94.text:
The best mentor relationships don't
start off as a financial arrangement.

339.49.text: You shouldn't be paying your mentors.

341.50.text:
Although that relationship
might change over time.

345.25.text:
is that they agree to give you
their time and effort

347.79.text:
because they believe in you,
and your vision, and your idea.

350.97.text:
So if they're asking
for money from day one,

354.24.text:
it's completely the wrong choice
in a mentor and you should run a mile.

358.07.text:
But the other thing is that mentors
are like any other employee,

361.20.text: you need to take references out on them.

363.25.text:
So just so somebody
wants to be your mentor

366.37.text:
and you think that they have succeeded,
I think you should talk to your peers,

370.31.text:
your colleagues, other people
they've mentored in the past,

373.24.text:
and find out if they've
really done a good job.

379.89.text:
You got to spend time with these people,
they've got to share your values.

383.57.text:
And you've got to enjoy
each other's company

385.73.text:
because hopefully it's going
to be a long, long journey together,

388.88.text:
you'll be seeing each other regularly,
and it's important you get along.

394.34.text:
The most important quality
of a mentor is to tell you the truth

398.17.text:
in a completely unadulterated fashion,
if you like in a blunt fashion.

402.32.text:
You don't want people to sugar coat
their words and their advice.

406.37.text: And if you cannot take their bluntness,

409.24.text:
you shouldn't really be
an entrepreneur in the first place.

412.17.text:
In criticism and helping you
avoid the rocks on your journey

417.16.text:
so they must be prepared to tell
the pure, unadulterated truth,

420.28.text: and you must be prepared to listen.

423.63.text:
I think the most important skill
of the mentor is to be a great listener.

427.97.text:
If they do not listen to you
and your problems,

430.51.text:
how are they really going to solve
them and think them through?

434.30.text:
In my head there are two types
of successful people:

437.35.text: one of whom is very ego driven.

439.91.text: They like the sound of their own voice

442.15.text:
and when you listen to them,
or overhear them

444.44.text:
giving a mentoring session
to somebody else,

446.70.text:
it is all about them,
and they are talking all the time.

449.77.text:
But actually, that's not
very helpful for you.

452.15.text: You don't want to know what they've done,

454.16.text:
you want their opinion
on what you've done.

456.22.text:
So being a listener
and an effective listener,

458.52.text:
and then telling that truth back to you
is the most important thing.

462.06.text:
It is also very important
from a mentor's point of view

465.66.text:
to take a step back and realize you are
no longer the one in the driving seat.

469.46.text:
Your job is to advise,
to whisper in their ear,

471.99.text: to help them through their problems,

474.12.text:
but at the end of the day
it is their decisions.

476.61.text:
The reason why those successful people
I've mentioned earlier are great founders

480.84.text:
is because they ask
lots of people their advice,

483.28.text: and they listen to lots of advice,

485.32.text:
and then they come up
with their own decision.

487.58.text:
They are in the driver's seat,
and it is no longer the entrepreneur

490.89.text:
or the mentor who is actually being
the successful one here.

494.68.text: A mentor needs to be upbeat and positive.

497.99.text:
God knows being a founder,
an entrepreneur,

501.23.text: is a really tough thing to do.

503.41.text:
It's probably the most tough thing
you can ever do in business.

506.54.text:
And it's going to be a rocky ride
even in the best startups.

510.05.text:
So your mentors need to be
your greatest supporters

512.69.text: and help lift you up when you feel down.

515.90.text:
And when you are going through that grind
when everything seems to be going wrong,

521.66.text: So how do you get a mentor?

525.13.text:
I think the hack here, the easy way
to do it if you were a startup

528.67.text:
is to join one of the world-class
accelerator programs that exist these days

533.41.text: which are very much driven by mentoring.

539.00.text: TechStars is one I mentor at, in London.

543.71.text:
But there are 1,500 applications
for every 10 seeds.

549.63.text: Y Combinator is another great one.

551.79.text:
You can tell by an accelerator
how effective they are

554.77.text: by the quality of their mentors.

557.05.text:
It's not just about the people
they've got on their website,

560.04.text:
it's are they going to work hard
and actually do some mentoring,

563.42.text: rather than just lend their names to it.

566.38.text:
It's not for everybody,
going to an accelerator.

571.45.text:
How would you go about doing that
if you didn't go into an accelerator?

576.84.text: Well,, there are a couple of ways:

578.79.text:
one of which is you can ask them
for a cup of coffee.

581.68.text:
Seriously, never ask them
for a cup of coffee.

584.48.text:
I get 80 cups of coffee offers
every month,

587.43.text:
and even in the best possible way
I could never take it all up.

591.11.text:
It's also, even if I wanted to,
an impossible use of my time.

597.15.text:
And anyway it's not being very creative
at the end of the day, as an entrepreneur.

601.22.text:
You need to tap into
your inner-Steve Jobs,

610.89.text:
and work at how you can
actually get peoples attention.

615.09.text:
So, one way, as an example,
which I've seen very effective

618.95.text:
is to find out what your
prospective mentor wants in life,

622.37.text:
what they are interested in,
and see if you can be useful.

625.27.text:
So perhaps your expected mentor
will be giving a TEDx talk

628.14.text:
in a couple of months time,
and could you help with the slides,

631.10.text:
could you help with the sounding board,
could you help them rehearse,

635.72.text:
Or if they are really into charity,
can you help them in some way?

638.92.text:
Another very effective way
I've seen doing it

641.65.text:
is to ask them a specific question
and ask for a 10 minute Skype call.

645.38.text:
That's very easy for me to turn down
an hour's cup of coffee,

648.61.text: but I'll probably make the time,

650.54.text:
as indeed most people
who are into mentoring,

653.05.text:
to discuss a very specific topic
around a ten-minute Skype call.

657.91.text:
So again, that's a starting point,
and once you've started

661.57.text:
you can start building the relationship,
and who knows where it is going to end?

665.35.text: So I suppose my message today

667.67.text:
really is if you're a young person
wanting to make your way in the world,

672.43.text:
mentoring is a very important tool,
and it can accelerate your success.

677.74.text:
That's particularly the case
if you are a startup

680.28.text:
but also if you want
to learn any specific skill,

682.81.text:
ask someone who has done it before
to be your guide.

685.31.text:
And the other thing I'd like to say
is that if you have skills

688.34.text:
which the world can share,
you want to be a mentor,

692.35.text:
and I urge you
to take the plunge, it is great.
